etymology_text: From Middle English abrest, equivalent to a- (“on, at”) + breast, meaning “breasts (chests) in line, side-by-side and exactly equally advanced”; roughly “breast-by-breast”.

raw_glosses: Side by side and facing forward.

examples.text: On Sunday afternoon it was as dark as night, with barely room for two riders abreast on a gradient that touches 20%.
examples.ref: July 15, 2012, Richard Williams, “Tour de France 2012: Carpet tacks cannot force Bradley Wiggins off track”, in Guardian Unlimited

examples.text: The only path was narrow and rugged: two men could hardly walk abreast;
examples.ref: 1859, Thomas Babington Macaulay, The History of England from the Accession of James the Second

glosses: Side by side and facing forward.

raw_glosses: (figuratively) Alongside; parallel to.
glosses: Alongside; parallel to.

raw_glosses: Informed, well-informed, familiar, acquainted.
glosses: Informed, well-informed, familiar, acquainted.

raw_glosses: Followed by of or with: up to a certain level or line; equally advanced.

examples.text: She believes it is important to keep abreast of new scientific developments.

glosses: Followed by of or with: up to a certain level or line; equally advanced.

raw_glosses: (Scotland) Breast high (of an advancing wave).

examples.text: The west wind blew a tempest, and, according to the common expression, brought in the water [of the Solway] three foot abreast.

glosses: Breast high (of an advancing wave).

raw_glosses: (nautical) Side by side; also, opposite; on a line with the vessel's beam.
glosses: Side by side; also, opposite; on a line with the vessel's beam.

nautical: side by side; also, opposite; over against; on a line with the vessel's beam

raw_glosses: (obsolete) At the same time; simultaneously.

examples.text: Abreast therewith began a convocation.
examples.ref: 1842, Thomas Fuller, The Church History of Britain, From the birth of Jesus Christ until the year MDCXLVIII., volume 1, Third edition, page 412

glosses: At the same time; simultaneously.

etymology_text: From Middle English abrest, equivalent to a- (“on, at”) + breast, meaning “breasts (chests) in line, side-by-side and exactly equally advanced”; roughly “breast-by-breast”.

raw_glosses: Informed, well-informed, familiar, acquainted.

raw_glosses: Up to a certain level or line; equally advanced

examples.text: to keep abreast of [or with] the present state of science.

Some people are born with a vital and responsive energy. It not only enables them to keep abreast of the times; it qualifies them to furnish in their own personality a good bit of the motive power to the mad pace.

etymology_text: From Middle English abrest, equivalent to a- (“on, at”) + breast, meaning “breasts (chests) in line, side-by-side and exactly equally advanced”; roughly “breast-by-breast”.

raw_glosses: Abreast of; alongside.

examples.text: This ship sank abreast the island.

glosses: Abreast of; alongside.

head_templates.name: en-adj
head_templates.expansion: abortive (comparative more abortive, superlative most abortive)

etymology_text: First attested in 1382, with the meaning "causing stillbirth or miscarriage". From Middle English, from Old French abortif, from Latin abortīvus (“causing abortion”), from aborior (“miscarry, disappear”), from ab (“amiss”) + orior (“appear, be born, arise”).

raw_glosses: (obsolete) Produced by abortion; born prematurely and therefore unnatural.

examples.text: Thou elvish-marked, abortive, rooting hog!
examples.ref: c. 1593 (date written), William Shakespeare, “The Tragedy of Richard the Third:[…]”, in Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies[…] (First Folio), London: […] Isaac Iaggard, and Ed[ward] Blount, published 1623, OCLC 606515358, [Act I, scene iii]

glosses: Produced by abortion; born prematurely and therefore unnatural.

raw_glosses: Coming to nothing; failing in its effect. .

examples.text: an abortive attempt
He made a salutation, or, to speak nearer the truth, an ill-defined, abortive attempt at curtsy.
examples.ref: 1851, Nathaniel Hawthorne, chapter 7, in The House of the Seven Gables

examples.text: […] and with utter loss of being / Threatens him, plung'd in that abortive gulf.
The king in vain excused his hasty retreats and abortive enterprises
examples.ref: 1838, William H. Prescott, History of the Reign of Ferdinand and Isabella

glosses: Coming to nothing; failing in its effect. .

raw_glosses: (biology) Imperfectly formed or developed; rudimentary; sterile.

examples.text: an abortive organ
an abortive stamen
an abortive ovule

glosses: Imperfectly formed or developed; rudimentary; sterile.

examples.text: abortive medicines

glosses: Causing abortion; abortifacient

raw_glosses: (medicine) Cutting short; acting to halt or slow the progress (of a disease).

examples.text: abortive treatment of typhoid fever

glosses: Cutting short; acting to halt or slow the progress (of a disease).

raw_glosses: Made from the skin of a still-born animal.

examples.text: abortive vellum

glosses: Made from the skin of a still-born animal.

etymology_text: First attested in 1382, with the meaning "causing stillbirth or miscarriage". From Middle English, from Old French abortif, from Latin abortīvus (“causing abortion”), from aborior (“miscarry, disappear”), from ab (“amiss”) + orior (“appear, be born, arise”).

raw_glosses: (obsolete) Someone or something born or brought forth prematurely; an abortion.

examples.text: Thou elvish-mark'd, abortive, rooting hog!

glosses: Someone or something born or brought forth prematurely; an abortion.

glosses: A fruitless effort.

glosses: A medicine to which is attributed the property of causing abortion, abortifacient.

head_templates.name: en-verb
head_templates.expansion: abortive (third-person singular simple present abortives, present participle abortiving, simple past and past participle abortived)

etymology_text: First attested in 1382, with the meaning "causing stillbirth or miscarriage". From Middle English, from Old French abortif, from Latin abortīvus (“causing abortion”), from aborior (“miscarry, disappear”), from ab (“amiss”) + orior (“appear, be born, arise”).

raw_glosses: (transitive, obsolete) To cause an abortion; to render without fruit.
glosses: To cause an abortion; to render without fruit.

etymology_text: From Middle English able, from Old Northern French able, variant of Old French abile, habile, from Latin habilis (“easily managed, held, or handled; apt; skillful”), from habeō (“have, possess”) + -ibilis.

etymology_templates.name: der

args.t: easily managed, held, or handled; apt; skillful

etymology_templates.expansion: Latin habilis (“easily managed, held, or handled; apt; skillful”)

raw_glosses: Having the necessary powers or the needed resources to accomplish a task.
glosses: Having the necessary powers or the needed resources to accomplish a task.

raw_glosses: Free from constraints preventing completion of task; permitted to; not prevented from.

examples.text: I’ll see you as soon as I’m able.
With that obstacle removed, I am now able to proceed with my plan.
I’m only able to visit you when I have other work here.
That cliff is able to be climbed.

glosses: Free from constraints preventing completion of task; permitted to; not prevented from.

raw_glosses: Gifted with skill, intelligence, knowledge, or competence.

examples.text: The chairman was also an able sailor.

Natures that haue much Heat, and great and violent deſires and Perturbations, are not ripe for Action, till they haue paſſed the Meridian of their yeares: As it was with Iulius Cæſar, and Septimius Seuerus. […] And yet he [Septimus Severus] was the Ableſt Emperour, almoſt, of all the Liſt.
examples.ref: 1625, Francis [Bacon], “Of Youth and Age. XLII.”, in The Essayes[…], 3rd edition, London: […] Iohn Haviland for Hanna Barret, OCLC 863521290, pages 247–248

glosses: Gifted with skill, intelligence, knowledge, or competence.

raw_glosses: (law) Legally qualified or competent.

examples.text: He is able to practice law in six states.

glosses: Legally qualified or competent.

raw_glosses: (nautical) Capable of performing all the requisite duties; as an able seaman.
glosses: Capable of performing all the requisite duties; as an able seaman.

raw_glosses: (obsolete, dialectal) Having the physical strength; robust; healthy.

examples.text: After the past week of forced marches, only half the men are fully able.

glosses: Having the physical strength; robust; healthy.

raw_glosses: (obsolete) Easy to use.

examples.text: As the hands are the most habil parts of the body...
examples.ref: 1710, Thomas Betterton, The life of Mr. Thomas Betterton, the late eminent tragedian.

glosses: Easy to use.

raw_glosses: (obsolete) Suitable; competent.

examples.text: […] and for every able man servant that he or she shall carry or send armed and provided as aforesaid, ninety acres of land of like measure.
examples.ref: 2006, Jon L. Wakelyn, America's Founding Charters: Primary Documents of Colonial and Revolutionary Era Governance, volume 1, Greenwood Publishing Group, page 212

glosses: Suitable; competent.

raw_glosses: (obsolete, dialectal) Liable to.
glosses: Liable to.

raw_glosses: (obsolete) Rich; well-to-do.

examples.text: He was born to an able family.

glosses: Rich; well-to-do.

head_templates.expansion: able (third-person singular simple present ables, present participle abling, simple past and past participle abled)

etymology_text: From Middle English ablen, from Middle English able (adjective).

glosses: To make ready.

raw_glosses: (transitive, obsolete) To vouch for; to guarantee.

examples.text: None does offend, none....I’ll able ’em.
examples.ref: c. 1603–1606, William Shakespeare, “The Tragedie of King Lear”, in Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies[…] (First Folio), London: […] Isaac Iaggard, and Ed[ward] Blount, published 1623, OCLC 606515358, [Act IV, scene vi]

glosses: To vouch for; to guarantee.
